text: it was a very difficult meeting and it
was highly emotionally charged and there
was a number of colleagues were very
very upset during the meeting including
myself
and there were there were a number of
threats made there are a number of votes
that were obviously crucial in
determining the future of the Liberal
Party and there were a number of
incidents which I thought were not
acceptable it's obviously very
distressing and thank you for talking to
us in the light of what you clearly feel
about it when you say there were threats
made can you expand on that a bit yep so
and when we met there were a number of
papers put in front of the the NAC one
of those was a letter that had been sent
to the party's general secretary and
threatening legal action against the
party and the National Executive
Committee High Court action if Jeremy
was not allowed to go into the ballot
paper automatic claim and so High Court
action the the letter also indicated
that if the NEC decided to conduct their
business by secret ballot that they
would seek court orders to review the
results of secret ballots and also that
the Liberal Party's general secretary
would be held legally liable personally
legally liable for and for that High
Court action there was there were a
number of other incidents so for example
Andy Burnham presented to the National
Executive Committee a proposal and from
mediation and at the end of his
statement he said that if the NEC did
not adopt his proposal that the the
Shadow Cabinet would have to meet later
that day to consider the legal advice
that had been put in front of the
National Executive Committee the
governing body of the Labour Party he
was effectively saying that the Shadow
Cabinet would consider legal advice on
our decision
the ballots on on whether or not Jeremy
Corbyn should be automatically
entered for the leadership was a secret
one to what extent was that decision
driven by people's worried about the
sorts of things you were talking about
people's worry that if the ballot was
open they would be threatened and
intimidated it was it that was the whole
debate about whether or not there should
be a secret ballot I want to say that I
am very happy as a member of the NEC to
be Hotere Koch for any decisions I take
on the NAC and I will release my vote
when I send out my NEC report and I'll
send that out with an explanation of my
fault the difficulty was that a number
of us and a number of my colleagues in
that room I had been subject to billing
and intimidation prior to the meeting
taking place and certain groups with
certain groups within the party
published my contact my personal contact
details online and one of my colleagues
has just recently heard I stock her
sectioned she was in tears she begged
the leader for a secret ballot and to
protect her and also other colleagues
who had received intimidating and
bullying behavior and the the thing that
really upset me about that meeting was
that the Labour Party leader voted
against the proposal to have a secret
ballot to protect colleagues so just to
be clear about what you're saying with
that last comment he of course yesterday
as you'll remember spoke out against
intimidation and violence in the
campaign but you feel that when it came
to it and when the crucial decision has
to be made he didn't back something that
would have protected people exactly
that's and that that is the the most
upsetting thing for for for me as a
member of the NEC I know that Tommy has
consistently spoken against bullying
behavior and I and I applaud him for
that and I respect that but when it came
to the fort to protect colleagues taking
an extremely difficult decision that
would determine the future of our party
he voted against the single thing that
he could have done to protect those
colleagues
